awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The evolutionary genetics of cellular and biochemical adaptation in Drosophila
awd_abstract_narration:
DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The evolutionary genetics of cellular and biochemical adaptation in Drosophila.

PI: Kristi L. Montooth
Co-PI: Brandon S. Cooper

Abstract:

Organisms experience variable environments in both space and time. Variation in factors like temperature and toxic compounds can cause natural selection that results in adaptation to local conditions. At the mechanistic level, these adaptations involve changes in physiological and cellular processes in response to the environment. This research will use techniques from molecular biology, analytical chemistry, genetics and physiology to evaluate the impact of environmental temperature on cell membranes, and of environmental toxicity (e.g., ethanol) on the activities of three enzymes in the ethanol detoxification pathway. Specifically, the research aims to test the prediction that variable temperature environments favor the evolution of cell membrane remodeling, and that efficient detoxification of ethanol depends on interactions between the three enzymes in this pathway. These data will then be used to construct new evolutionary models that help predict the responses of organisms to changing environments.

This project will provide opportunities for undergraduate students from groups underrepresented in the sciences to participate in the research. Outreach to elementary school children at a disadvantaged school, where only 70% passed the state proficiency test for science, will increase scientific literacy. The co-PI collaborates with the local elementary school teachers, providing experiences for the students in basic science and teaching the process of scientific inquiry. Projects will be developed enabling teachers to improve science education at their school. Because this research evaluates the evolution of organismal responses to changing temperatures, the results will also enable the PI and co-PI to provide a better understanding of how organisms respond and adapt to changing environments. Further, the populations of flies collected and constructed will be made available to the scientific community.

por.por_cntn:
Organisms face daily and seasonal changes in their environment. This is particularly challenging for ectotherms – the vast majority of organisms on the planet – that rely on external environmental temperatures to maintain their internal body temperatures. Organisms use diverse strategies to maintain function as their environment changes. A common strategy is to adjust physiology, either during development or within the lifetime of adult individuals, to match the environment – a process called plasticity. This project generated critical information on the genetic, biochemical and evolutionary mechanisms that allow for physiological plasticity of a model ectotherm – Drosophila melanogaster, a fruit fly – and that maintain cellular function when the environment changes. Several of the mechanisms we investigated are largely used by and conserved from bacteria to humans, such that our findings are relevant to how many organisms deal with changes to their external environment.

A key finding of this research is that populations of flies that experience more thermal change in their environment across seasons have evolved greater plasticity to maintain the cell membrane – a critical component of how cells function – and this corresponds to increased female reproduction across a range of temperatures. Other experiments tested whether responses to the environment were similar or different between life stages. These experiments found that similar genes are responsible for the cell membrane responses of juveniles and adults to temperature, but that different genes are responsible for adult cell membrane responses to increased temperature versus decreased temperature. In contrast, responses to environmental ethanol were found to differ between juveniles and adult flies. These experiments inform our understanding of how organisms, from flies to humans, maintain physiology and reproduction when environments change. In addition, these data provide insight into what genes are responsible for how organisms tolerate ethanol – a common dietary component for organisms that eat fermented fruit and nectar that becomes toxic to cells at higher concentrations. These studies were published in a PhD thesis and the data have been made publically available. 

Finally, a large dataset was generated to compare how juvenile and adult flies tolerate ethanol when they are exposed to different environmental temperatures. This experiment generated information on how changes in the ethanol and temperature environment affect the activity of genes across the entire genome. Current analysis of these data will identify genetic pathways that are responsible for the cellular and physiological plasticity that this project investigated. These results will be published in at least two peer-reviewed articles, and the data will be made publicly available.

The project supported community engagement to increase representation of lower socioeconomic groups in the sciences. Researchers worked with 4th grade teachers at a local elementary school, where many students are economically disadvantaged and only 70% of students passed the state proficiency test for science. Researchers assisted teachers in getting funding for scientific projects in their classrooms, visited classrooms on career days, and designed and implemented a gardening project that students did from start to finish, from mathematics of design to harvest and delivery of goods to a local food bank. Finally, this project supported the PhD training of a first-generation college student, who is now an assistant professor at a major state university, as well as the training of multiple women who are all continuing in STEM careers.
